natural problem: How many ways can I put down two indistinguishable pieces on an ordinary $8\times 8$ chessboard, if the pieces must either be in the same row or be in the same column?
natural solution: The first piece can go in any of the $64$ squares. The second piece can then be in any of $14$ positions, since there are $7$ unoccupied squares in the row of the first piece, as well as $7$ unoccupied squares in the column of the first piece.
This would seem to give us $64\cdot 14$ choices for the placement of the two pieces.
However, order doesn't matter (we said the pieces are indistinguishable), so the actual number of choices is $(64\cdot 14)/2$, which is $\boxed{448}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = 64 choose 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. f n = 8 * (8 choose 2) + 8 * (8 choose 2)"
shows  "f 64 = 448"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways can I put down two indistinguishable pieces on an ordinary $8\times 8$ chessboard, if the pieces must either be in the same row or be in the same column? The final Answer is 448
 ### Proof
 The first piece can go in any of the $64$ squares. The second piece can then be in any of $14$ positions, since there are $7$ unoccupied squares in the row of the first piece, as well as $7$ unoccupied squares in the column of the first piece.
 This would seem to give us $64\cdot 14$ choices for the placement of the two pieces.
 However, order doesn't matter (we said the pieces are indistinguishable), so the actual number of choices is $(64\cdot 14)/2$, which is $\boxed{448}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = 64 choose 2"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. f n = 8 * (8 choose 2) + 8 * (8 choose 2)"
shows  "f 64 = 448"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: The function $f$ is defined for all natural numbers $n$ such that $f(n)$ is equal to the number of ways to choose 2 items from a set of 64 items. This is also equal to 8 times the number of ways to choose 2 items from a set of 8 items plus 8 times the number of ways to choose 2 items from another set of 8 items. What is the value of $f(64)$? The final answer is 448.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 8"
shows  "2 * n * (n * (n - 1) div 2) = 448"

 This would seem to give us $64\cdot 14$ choices for the placement of the two pieces.
 However, order doesn't matter (we said the pieces are indistinguishable), so the actual number of choices is $(64\cdot 14)/2$, which is $\boxed{448}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 8"
shows  "2 * n * (n * (n - 1) div 2) = 448"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: If $n = 8$, calculate the value of $2n \times \frac{n(n - 1)}{2}$. The final Answer is $448$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "f(1) = 64"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> f n = f (n-1) + 7"
shows  "f 64 = 448"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways can I put down two indistinguishable pieces on an ordinary $8\times 8$ chessboard, if the pieces must either be in the same row or be in the same column? The final Answer is 448
 ### Proof
 The first piece can go in any of the $64$ squares. The second piece can then be in any of $14$ positions, since there are $7$ unoccupied squares in the row of the first piece, as well as $7$ unoccupied squares in the column of the first piece.
 This would seem to give us $64\cdot 14$ choices for the placement of the two pieces.
 However, order doesn't matter (we said the pieces are indistinguishable), so the actual number of choices is $(64\cdot 14)/2$, which is $\boxed{448}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "f(1) = 64"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> f n = f (n-1) + 7"
shows  "f 64 = 448"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A function $f$ is defined recursively by $f(1)=64$ and for all integers $n \geq 2$, $f(n) = f(n-1) + 7$. What is the value of $f(64)$? The final answer is $448$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n m p :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 8"
and h1 : "m = 8"
and h2 : "p = 2"
shows  "fact(n) div (fact(p) * fact(n - p)) * n + fact(m) div (fact(p) * fact(m - p)) * m - n * m = 448"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways can I put down two indistinguishable pieces on an ordinary $8\times 8$ chessboard, if the pieces must either be in the same row or be in the same column? The final Answer is 448
 ### Proof
 The first piece can go in any of the $64$ squares. The second piece can then be in any of $14$ positions, since there are $7$ unoccupied squares in the row of the first piece, as well as $7$ unoccupied squares in the column of the first piece.
 This would seem to give us $64\cdot 14$ choices for the placement of the two pieces.
 However, order doesn't matter (we said the pieces are indistinguishable), so the actual number of choices is $(64\cdot 14)/2$, which is $\boxed{448}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n m p :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 8"
and h1 : "m = 8"
and h2 : "p = 2"
shows  "fact(n) div (fact(p) * fact(n - p)) * n + fact(m) div (fact(p) * fact(m - p)) * m - n * m = 448"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Calculate the value of the expression "$\frac{n!}{p!(n-p)!}n + \frac{m!}{p!(m-p)!}m - nm$" given that $n = 8, m = 8$, and $p = 2$. The final answer is 448.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes chessboard :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 8 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 8 \<longrightarrow> chessboard i j = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> i j k. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 8 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 8 \<and> 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 8 \<longrightarrow> (chessboard i k = 1 \<or> chessboard k j = 1)"
shows  "card {(i, j, k). 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 8 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 8 \<and> 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 8 \<and> (chessboard i k = 1 \<or> chessboard k j = 1)} = 448"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways can I put down two indistinguishable pieces on an ordinary $8\times 8$ chessboard, if the pieces must either be in the same row or be in the same column? The final Answer is 448
 ### Proof
 The first piece can go in any of the $64$ squares. The second piece can then be in any of $14$ positions, since there are $7$ unoccupied squares in the row of the first piece, as well as $7$ unoccupied squares in the column of the first piece.
 This would seem to give us $64\cdot 14$ choices for the placement of the two pieces.
 However, order doesn't matter (we said the pieces are indistinguishable), so the actual number of choices is $(64\cdot 14)/2$, which is $\boxed{448}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes chessboard :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 8 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 8 \<longrightarrow> chessboard i j = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> i j k. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 8 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 8 \<and> 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 8 \<longrightarrow> (chessboard i k = 1 \<or> chessboard k j = 1)"
shows  "card {(i, j, k). 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 8 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 8 \<and> 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 8 \<and> (chessboard i k = 1 \<or> chessboard k j = 1)} = 448"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Consider a 8x8 chessboard where each square is marked with the number 1. For all rows (i), columns (j) and another variable (k) that range from 1 to 8, either the square at row i and column k is marked with 1, or the square at row k and column j is marked with 1. What is the total number of such (i, j, k) triples? The final answer is 448.

 *)

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes chessboard :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. chessboard x y = (if (x \<in> {1..8} \<and> y \<in> {1..8}) then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. chessboard x y = chessboard y x"
and h2 : "sum (\<lambda>(x,y). chessboard x y) (SIGMA x: {1..8}. {1..8}) = 448"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>x. (chessboard x) ^ 2) {1..8} = 448"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways can I put down two indistinguishable pieces on an ordinary $8\times 8$ chessboard, if the pieces must either be in the same row or be in the same column? The final Answer is 448
 ### Proof
 The first piece can go in any of the $64$ squares. The second piece can then be in any of $14$ positions, since there are $7$ unoccupied squares in the row of the first piece, as well as $7$ unoccupied squares in the column of the first piece.
 This would seem to give us $64\cdot 14$ choices for the placement of the two pieces.
 However, order doesn't matter (we said the pieces are indistinguishable), so the actual number of choices is $(64\cdot 14)/2$, which is $\boxed{448}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes chessboard :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. chessboard x y = (if (x \<in> {1..8} \<and> y \<in> {1..8}) then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. chessboard x y = chessboard y x"
and h2 : "sum (\<lambda>(x,y). chessboard x y) (SIGMA x: {1..8}. {1..8}) = 448"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>x. (chessboard x) ^ 2) {1..8} = 448"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Consider a chessboard defined such that each square is labelled by 1 if it is within an 8x8 grid (the actual chessboard), and 0 otherwise. The chessboard is symmetric, so the value of a square at coordinates (x, y) is the same as at (y, x). If the sum of the values of all squares within the 8x8 grid is 448, what is the sum of the squares of the values of the squares along one side of the chessboard? The final answer is 448.
